ygData.subject: Double Pole Balancing Questions
ygData.msgSnippet: First off, we went back and looked at Ken s code to compare it with Colin s port, and we did notice some code for randomizing the initial state of the system:

First off, we went back and looked at Ken's code to compare it with
Colin's=
 port, and we did notice some code for randomizing the initial
state of the=
 system:

   if (random_start) {
     /*set up random start state*/
     x =
=3D (lrand48()%4800)/1000.0 - 2.4;
     x_dot =3D (lrand48()%2000)/1000.0 -=
 1;
     theta =3D (lrand48()%400)/1000.0 - .2;
     theta_dot =3D (lrand48=
()%3000)/1000.0 - 1.5;
    }
   else 
     x =3D x_dot =3D theta =3D theta_=
dot =3D 0.0;

Though we didn't notice this code in Colin's port...so did yo=
u every
do any experiments with this code Ken?

And we have some other ques=
tions:

1) When the state is initialized for the double pole balancing tria=
ls,
0.07 is used as the value for one degree:

	// Initialise state. 
	stat=
e[0] =3D state[1] =3D state[3] =3D state[4] =3D state[5] =3D 0;
	state[2] =
=3D 0.07; // one_degree;

Is this a typo?  It is in both Ken and Colin's co=
de.  Shouldn't one
degree be 0.017?  If it is radians, that works out to be=
 around 4
degrees.  Some of the more commonly used constants are declared a=
s
shortcuts earlier in the code, e.g.:

   double one_degree=3D 0.0174532;	=
/* 2pi/360 */

We just replaced 0.07 with the variable "one_degree".  Is th=
is right?

2) When the environmental state values are normalized for input =
into
the network, they are handled differently in single and double pole
ba=
lancing.  For single:

	// Provide state info to the network (normalised to=
 0 to 1.0).
	network.setInputSignal(0, (cart_pos_x + trackLength/2.0) / tra=
ckLength);
	network.setInputSignal(1, (cart_velocity_x + 0.75) /1.5);
	netw=
ork.setInputSignal(2, (pole_angle + twelve_degrees) / twentyfour_degrees);
=
	network.setInputSignal(3, (pole_angular_velocity + 1.0) / 2.0);


For doub=
le:

	network.setInputSignal(0, state[0] / trackLength);
	network.setInputS=
ignal(1, state[1] / 2.0);
	network.setInputSignal(2, state[2] / 0.52);
	net=
work.setInputSignal(3, state[3] / 2.0);
	network.setInputSignal(4, state[4]=
 / 0.52);
	network.setInputSignal(5, state[5] / 2.0);

Why are these differ=
ent?

For double it seems like you don't actually get values scaled between=

0 and 1 or -1 and 1.

3) Are 100,000 time steps necessary?  It seems to us=
 that all networks
we've looked at so far either fail or succeed very early=
 in each
trial, (e.g., <10,000 timesteps).  This would greatly increase
eff=
iciency to truncate the amount of timesteps.

That's it for now...thanks in=
 advance for any answers...

Derek
